JUDGES: Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Sverre Erik Jebens;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented by ORG , a firm of solicitors based in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP By application to the Chief Electoral Officer for GPE dated DATE , the applicant sought inclusion in the electoral register for GPE . The applicant was at the time of the application a serving prisoner , detained in FAC Maghaberry . The application was made in view of the pending elections to ORG , to be held on DATE . The deadline for registration in order to vote in the elections of CARDINAL DATE was DATE . At the date of this deadline the applicant was serving sentences of imprisonment totalling DATE imposed in DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated CARDINAL DATE , the application was refused . The Chief Electoral Officer concluded that by virtue of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Representation of the People Act DATE ( as amended ) the applicant was legally incapable of voting as a result of his status as a convicted person currently detained ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant , together with another serving prisoner , lodged an application for judicial review of the decision of the Chief Electoral Officer . He sought various forms of relief , including a declaration that the disqualification on convicted prisoners voting contained in sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act did not apply to the forthcoming or any future election to ORG ; a declaration that he was entitled to vote in the forthcoming and any future election to ORG ; damages for a breach of his rights under the Convention ; and a declaration that LAW Order CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) was not compatible with LAW No . CARDINAL and should not be applied to the forthcoming or any future election to ORG .

CARDINAL . In the context of the judicial review proceedings , counsel for the ORG submitted that even if , in light of this ORG ’s judgment in ORG v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALIX , the Government pursued the option of permitting some prisoners to vote depending on the length of their sentence , they were unlikely to propose that prisoners serving sentences as long as the applicant ’s should become entitled to vote while detained . It was further pointed out that the applicant had failed to submit his application to be enrolled on the electoral register by the deadline for participation in the elections of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG of GPE dismissed the application for judicial review . PERSON considered that the judgment in ORG , cited above , gave a margin of appreciation to GPE in deciding how to ensure respect for the rights guaranteed by LAW No . CARDINAL . Accordingly , he concluded :

“ CARDINAL(iv ) . I consider that the [ GPE ] court has deliberately left the method of compliance in the hands of ORG subject to the overriding veto of the court ... Accordingly I see nothing intrinsically objectionable about the various options being explored by the Government proposals contained in the consultation paper of DATE which makes up its response to the ORG decision . The consequence of this is that not only is Mr PERSON [ Deputy Director , Rights and International Relations in ORG at ORG ] entitled to say ... that the Government is unlikely to propose that prisoners serving sentences as long as those of the applicants should become entitled to vote whilst detained , but I am left singularly unconvinced that the applicants are currently or will ever be able to lay claim to a right to vote . I reject the argument of Mr PERSON [ for the applicants ] that because a blanket prohibition on prisoners is incompatible with the Convention that somehow converts into the proposition that all prisoners are currently entitled to vote until the vacuum is filled . In my view that conforms neither with principle nor logic and certainly does not find any authority in ORG which expressly recognises that restraints on LAW are justifiable provided they pursue a legitimate aim and are proportionate . ”
CARDINAL . He added :

“ Notwithstanding their knowledge since DATE that an election was to be in the near future , these proceedings were not launched until DATE at a time when the granting of the relief sought would have caused potentially the maximum confusion , disruption and waste of public money already incurred . This is particularly pertinent in the context of both applicants having failed even to apply to register to vote in time . These factors alone should extinguish any smouldering sense of injustice harboured by these applicants at this time . ”
CARDINAL . The applicant was released from prison on DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused leave to appeal .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Representation of the People Act DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) provides :
“ ( CARDINAL ) A convicted person during the time that he is detained in a penal institution in pursuance of his sentence ... is legally incapable of voting at any parliamentary or local election . ”

CARDINAL . NORP The disqualification does not apply to persons imprisoned for contempt of court ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) ) or to those imprisoned only for default in , for example , paying a fine ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(c ) ) .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act provides :
“ ( CARDINAL ) A person is entitled to be registered in the register of parliamentary electors for any constituency or part of a constituency if on the relevant date he–
( a ) is resident in the constituency or that part of it ;
( b ) is not subject to any legal incapacity to vote ( age apart ) ;
( CARDINAL ) A person is entitled to be registered in the register of local government electors for any electoral area if on the relevant date he–
( a ) is resident in that area ;
( b ) is not subject to any legal incapacity to vote ( age apart ) ;
CARDINAL . ORG ( Elections ) Order DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) provides as follows :

“ CARDINAL . A person is entitled to vote at an ORG election in a constituency if on DATE of the poll he would be entitled to vote as an elector at a local election in a district electoral area wholly or partly comprised in that constituency . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( “ LAW ” ) provides as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) So far as it is possible to do so , primary legislation and subordinate legislation must be read and given effect in a way which is compatible with the Convention rights .
( CARDINAL ) This section-
( a ) applies to primary legislation and subordinate legislation whenever enacted ;
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW provides :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Subsection ( CARDINAL ) applies in any proceedings in which a court determines whether a provision of primary legislation is compatible with a Convention right .
( CARDINAL ) NORP If the court is satisfied that the provision is incompatible with a Convention right , it may make a declaration of that incompatibility .

CARDINAL . Finally , section DATE ) of the LAW provides that it is unlawful for a public authority to act in a way which is incompatible with a LAW right . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) clarifies that :
“ Subsection ( CARDINAL ) does not apply to an act if–
( a ) as the result of CARDINAL or more provisions of primary legislation , the authority could not have acted differently ; or

( b ) in the case of CARDINAL or more provisions of , or made under , primary legislation which can not be read or given effect in a way which is compatible with the Convention rights , the authority was acting so as to give effect to or enforce those provisions . ”

CARDINAL . In PERSON v. PERSON SLT CARDINAL , ORG in GPE considered the refusal of ORG for GPE , GPE and GPE to enrol a convicted prisoner on the electoral register on the basis of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act , in anticipation of elections to ORG . The Secretary of ORG conceded in the proceedings that in light of the judgment of this ORG in ORG , cited above , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act was incompatible with LAW No . CARDINAL to the LAW and that the appellant ’s rights under that LAW had been violated . He also accepted that for the purposes of LAW No . CARDINAL ORG was a legislature .

CARDINAL . The Registration Appeal Court handed down its judgment on DATE . It declined to “ read down ” the electoral legislation pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) in order to allow serving prisoners to vote . However , it made a declaration of incompatibility in respect of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . Further details of legal challenges brought by serving prisoners in the various jurisdictions of GPE are set out in the ORG ’s judgment in NORP and PERSON v. GPE , nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE .
